Basically Balatro but with Mahjong, and you get even more items and stuff to mess with the rules. If you don't know mahjong it seems really confusing at first, but it is actually really easy to learn, so you can play this even if you never played Mahjong before.

Basically the goal is to get a pairs and sets. A set is either a 3 of a kind, or 3 in a row of the same suit(so for example bamboo is a suit, 1, 2, 3 of a bamboo is a set). You always have 13 tiles in your hand, so each turn you draw some tiles and you can swap them freely with the tiles in your hand, then your opponent has a chance to draw from those left over tiles. If you use your oppenent's tiles it has to make a set, and they are locked in so you can't change your mind later.

You are always one tile short of making your last set/pair. When you have everything else you declare you are ready and then basically just draw tiles for that missing piece of the set. Every time you get one of them, you score points. The number of times you can score is capped  but can be changed with items and stuff. You get extra bonus points for special stuff, like having all of the sets be the same suit, or having a straight going across your entire hand. Though don't worry too much about that starting out. Just remember you need to get duplicates of tiles and ones that are in order. There are advanced patterns, but you can learn those as you go.

It's like Sky-High Ambition from Mahjong Soul, except it's a PvP roguelite.

Or, as simply stated many times in other reviews, it's Balatro for tiles.

Can get very interesting and very broken, very quickly, if you know what you're doing.  Every character has their strengths and weaknesses and everyone has their own way to make them shine if you're lucky enough to get them where you need to be.  The farther you get, the more broken the hands become but in the later difficulties you need that kind of power.

On the technical side of things, the one thing in this build that I'm not a fan of currently is the AI voice used for English or at least I'm almost certain of it being the case.  It's as simple as changing the options in audio but I can certain criticize its inclusion.  It would just be better without it, even if it is a placeholder.

Overall though, with that stated, it doesn't detract from the entire experience.  It's obvious that this game has a lot to go but this is the game that Aotenjo and the like would want to be that are trying to be the next big Balatro or deck-builder clone in the tile arena.  It's very fun and very engaging to those who are into this.  Anyone else...well, you might be surprised and you might end up getting into Mahjong itself over it. Balatro-Peglin Mahjong! What's not to like... unless you don't like those games. But if that is the case, why are you here?

Demonic Mahjong is another game that follows the steps of Balatro but instead of simply going for the same gambling roguelike idea, it pushes the formula forward by creating a new experience while staying true to the core of what made Balatro so enjoyable.

Instead of poker, you're playing Chinese Mahjong. Much like Balatro, you don't have to know Mahjong to play this game but being familiar with it certainly helps as the skill floor of Mahjong is a bit higher and this game makes it worse with the sheer amount of mechanics and different hand combinations.

Instead of facing a faceless enemy and trying to beat a specific score, here you're facing different opponents, each with their own playstyles and tools to hinder you. Not only that but the score to beat is not set in stone, it is based on much the opponent can score themselves, making each encounter far more interesting overall.

This game also offers a wider variety of builds. Unlike decks in Balatro, here you get to pick your own character and each character favors a playstyle or hands they wanna work towards to. For example, the starting character aims for a specific symbol so the favored hand combinations are about having tiles of the same symbol. My personal favorite character aims for pairs, you get the idea.
Your characters also different skills you can activate while in a match to give you a hand on getting the combinations you need.

BUT WAIT, THERE'S MORE!

You have a variety of items that gives you permanent buffs and consumables, some of them can be pretty damn busted so the game really encourages you to break the charts and get scores up to the millions (as you can see in the store page). Oh, I almost forgot that you ALSO have tile modifiers, you can increase their score value, change their numbers, symbols and add other effects much like you can do to cards in Balatro.

However, while the core gameplay of the game is pretty much perfect imo, the game is not free of a general lack of polish.
Animations are rough around the edges, some characters don't even have facial animations, the VA is lackluster and doesn't match the animations, audio balance is all over the place, there are still some text errors that can be found and the description of items can be very confusing.
Not a deal breaker for me but I know this lack of polish and "clunkiness" may diminish your experience and make the game less enjoyable so be wary of that.

Overall, great game that improves and does something unique with the Balatro formula.

Basically Balatro but with Mahjong, and you get even more items and stuff to mess with the rules. If you don't know mahjong it seems really confusing at first, but it is actually really easy to learn, so you can play this even if you never played Mahjong before.

Basically the goal is to get a pairs and sets. A set is either a 3 of a kind, or 3 in a row of the same suit(so for example bamboo is a suit, 1, 2, 3 of a bamboo is a set). You always have 13 tiles in your hand, so each turn you draw some tiles and you can swap them freely with the tiles in your hand, then your opponent has a chance to draw from those left over tiles. If you use your oppenent's tiles it has to make a set, and they are locked in so you can't change your mind later.

You are always one tile short of making your last set/pair. When you have everything else you declare you are ready and then basically just draw tiles for that missing piece of the set. Every time you get one of them, you score points. The number of times you can score is capped  but can be changed with items and stuff. You get extra bonus points for special stuff, like having all of the sets be the same suit, or having a straight going across your entire hand. Though don't worry too much about that starting out. Just remember you need to get duplicates of tiles and ones that are in order. There are advanced patterns, but you can learn those as you go.

I'm torn. The concept seems brilliant, Mahjong / Balatro / Slay the Spire, there is a lot of potential here. But I'm disappointed with the execution and gameplay balance, as they end up promoting boring, trivial strategies far too much for each run to feel unique.

The game is loosely based on the Riichi ruleset, which makes it approachable. Of course, there are various exceptions that make the game work in the context of two players, like you also draw four tiles at a time and discard four. There is also a giant collection of fun yaku, such as dragons-only chitoitsu or 13 copies of the same tile, which are fun to build. It's fun when you get them for the first time, but afterwards all the game has to offer are just ever-increasing points multipliers.

I've played six different characters (intended to promote completely different playstyles) across five difficulty levels, and not once found the intended playstyle worthwhile. Sticking to [spoiler]tsuiisou + suuankou + daisangen/daisuushii[/spoiler] is a much safer bet, as they easily [spoiler]combine into multi-yakumans. If you pay even a little attention to the choice of items & relics on each run, you can also reliably score what this game calls a "tenhou" but is actually a double riichi (a one-turn-kill, in a way)[/spoiler].

This approach removed the need for any strategic mindset in my runs. But there's more:

[list]
 [*]There is little reason to defend at all. No only furiten does not apply, but also the game does not end on a ron, so you don't need to win first. Just focus on scoring lots of points and you can pretty much ignore the opponent.
 [*]There is no dora to cause round-to-round asymmetries.
 [*]Harder waits don't offer greater rewards. Suuankou tanki is worth as much as a regular suuankou. Why bother gambling like a jackass then? There is no fu either, so even on simpler hands it never pays off to play something irregular.
 [*]Opponents come with their unique skills which I'm supposed to watch out for, but only very few matter at all, and none can stop me from just collecting honors.
 [*]The game consistently offers to little or too much control over tile modifiers (which you accumulate throughout each run). When applied randomly, they become completely inconsequential to the greater picture. When picked by the player, the choice offered is so vast, you can easily choose just what you need. Similarly, merchants, relic choices and events end up offering everything you might need for the specific playstyle you're going for, so there are rarely tough situations where you'll have to somehow deal with what you got.
 [*]Beyond that, I had a sense of playing an idle clicker game with their ever growing exponents, as with both mine and opponent's scores kept getting higher and higher on each difficulty level, not because I got more skilled, but because I was allowed to stack better bounes, and the opponents had various fixed difficulty-dependent modifiers. Yawn.
[/list]

So overall, this isn't nearly as fun as I originally expected it to be.

On the plus side, I can praise both character animations & visual effects. However, some of the video cutscenes are jarring and clearly AI-generated, I don't think the developer is being truthful by claiming to only have used AI in conceptual design stage.

The soundtrack is also pretty good, but it has very little variety; I felt like there were just 3 or 4 tracks total, so that got boring fairly quickly too.

If you're familiar with Mahjong (the real game, not the tile-match game using Mahjong tiles), it might be OK. If you don't have experience with the actual game, though, the quick explanation they give of the game is far too rushed. Expect a lot of confusion about what you're doing, and why.
